resources.string: This quiz tests random knowledge in astronomy. You can either evaluate each question separately or fill them all and get your overall score by pressing the GET SCORE button at the end. I hope you will enjoy this!
Which of these are examples of dying stars?
Which image shows Pluto the best known of Solar system‘s dwarf planets?
Which of these statements about NASA‘s New Horizons mission are true?
The probe‘s main target is dwarf planet Eris
It took 9 years (2006-2015) for the probe to fly from the Earth to it‘s target beyond Neptune
The next flyby around a transneptunian object is scheduled for 2035
If all goes as planned the spacecraft will eventually leave the Solar system
Which star can we find above the Norh Pole?\n(The answer is a name = it starts with a capital letter.)
In August 2017 an astronomical event was for the first time ever detected in both gravitational waves and electromagnetic spectrum simultaneously. What was it?
A supernova, i.e. a dying star exploding
A kilonova, i.e. two neutron stars merging into each other
Two blackholes merging into each other
Two galaxies merging into each other
Identify the object in this image:
Which of the following statements are true about planet Jupiter?
It is the biggest planet in the Solar system and has more mass than all other planets combined.
It has retrograde rotation, i.e. it rotates in opposite direction than Sun and other planets.
It has a system of rings.
Identify the object in this picture:\n(start your answer with a capital letter, you are looking for a name)
What is the nearest galaxy to Milky Way?
Which picture shows the far side of the moon?
Nope. Try again!\n(Hint: there are two correct answers.)
No, this is dwarf planet Eris.\nTry again!
No, this is dwarf planet Haumea.\nTry again!
No, this is dwarf planet Makemake.\nTry again!
Yes, the astronomers detected and saw a kilonova!
No. Two black holes merging was the first event detected by gravitational waves, but it was not seen in electromagnetic spectrum. Try again!
No, it\'s not the Moon. Try again!\nHint: this is a planet.
No, it\'s not Mercury, but you are close.\nTry again!
No, it\'s not Ceres. Try again!\nHint: this is a planet.
No, try again!\nHint: this is one of the planets.
This is the Moon, but the side we can see.\nTry again!
Oops! There are some questions without answer.\nTo get the score you have to answer all questions.
